recipes.html:
Engineering March 15, 2025 · 8 min read

Building a Zero-Build CSS Framework for the AI Age

Sarah Chen

Lead Engineer at Baseline

The way we build user interfaces is changing. With the rise of AI-powered code generation, the tools and frameworks we use need to evolve. What worked for human developers typing out code may not be optimal for language models generating it.

The Problem with Current Frameworks

Most CSS frameworks were designed with human developers in mind. Short, cryptic class names save keystrokes but create ambiguity. When an LLM encounters fw:700, it has to guess whether that means font-weight, flex-wrap, or something else entirely.

Predictability beats brevity. A framework that an LLM can use correctly 99% of the time is more valuable than one that saves a few characters.

Our Approach

Baseline CSS takes a different approach. Every class name is self-documenting. The domain:value syntax makes it immediately clear what each class does.

  • Self-documenting names reduce LLM errors by 80%
  • Zero build step means instant deployment
  • CSS-native approach is CSP-compliant by default
  • Composable themes via data attributes

recipes.html:
Frequently Asked Questions

Everything you need to know about the product.

Baseline CSS is designed from the ground up for LLM code generation. It uses self-documenting domain:value naming (bg:primary instead of bg-blue-500), requires zero build step, and includes a complete JSON reference schema that LLMs can consume for predictable output. It's also CSP-compliant and fully themeable via CSS custom properties.

No. Baseline CSS is a single static CSS file. Just link it in your HTML with a <link> tag and start using classes immediately. No npm, no PostCSS, no purging, no configuration files. It works with any framework or plain HTML.

Override the CSS custom properties in your own stylesheet. All design tokens (colors, spacing, typography, shadows) use CSS variables defined on :root. For example: :root { --primary: oklch(0.6 0.2 260); } changes the entire primary color palette including hover and active states.

Yes. Dark mode activates automatically via prefers-color-scheme, or you can set data-theme="dark" on your HTML element. Themes are composable — you can combine dark mode with high-contrast or large-text: data-theme="dark high-contrast".

All modern browsers: Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge. The CSS :has() selectors used for has-checked/has-focus variants require Chrome 105+, Safari 15.4+, and Firefox 121+, which covers 95%+ of active browsers.
